hi and welcome you listening to the x-22
report my name is Dave and this is
episode 1463 a.n today's date is January
4th 2018 and the top of the episode is
the economy is deteriorating and it's
spreading quickly let's get into the
economic collapse financial news now
yesterday we mentioned that Macy's was
closing 30 stores in total and they
already started to announce some of
their stores they said right off the bat
they're closing 7 then they're gonna be
looking at another 4 and then another 19
after that and we can see at this point
they're closing many stores and this is
not because sales are fantastic this is
because sales are plummeting even though
the corporate media is out there trying
to tell us that sales have been pretty
good same store sales are fantastic if
sales are doing well and they're
improving and everything's getting
better
you don't contract you expand and right
now when they close these stores there
is closing the store in Miami they're
closing the store in Gainesville Florida
they're closing one in California
they're closing another one in Indiana
Michigan Vermont Cincinnati and a lot of
people are gonna be losing their job
about 5,000 people will be losing their
jobs and it already looks like they're
getting ready to close even more stores
stores in Los Angeles San Francisco
Idaho and many others and they're
looking at even more than that we see
Sears is closing a hundred and three
stores this is on top of the 63 stores
closing at the end of this month and
Kmart is also closing stores we're going
to see a lot of retailers come out and
they're going to be making an
announcements that they're bankrupt they
are closing stores and we're going to
see this happen throughout this year is
it going to be as bad as it was in 2017
well we don't know yet because we don't
have the actual numbers we just had it
we just have what the corporate media
has been feeding us telling us that
everything is great but the proof is in
the pudding because what will happen is
stores will come out with their numbers
they'll say profits are down
and all of a sudden we're going to see
stores start to close because again we
don't have the actual numbers of what
the stores have been doing now does this
mean every store is doing poorly now
there'll be some stories that are doing
ok that are holding on and there'll be
other stories that are a complete
disaster because it doesn't hit everyone
all at once it hits a lot at once but
not everyone at the same exact time and
we can see this and go back to 2008 not
everyone was caught up in the 2008
recession some people made out very well
some people it was a complete disaster
they lost everything their business
their house their cars their families
broke up same thing in retail some
stores went out of business in 2017 shut
down for good never to be seen again
other stores were hanging on but what
we're seeing right now is a complete and
utter breakdown if we look at Auto Sales
well this is a complete and utter
disaster total new vehicle sales fell in
the US five five point two percent
year-over-year in December to one point
six million units for all of 2017 sales
decline by three hundred and twenty
thousand vehicles or 1.8 percent and
what we're seeing is that this was the
first overall decline since the
financial crisis now compared to 2015
sales fell by two hundred and forty nine
thousand vehicles or 1.4 percent and if
we look at some of these manufacturers
we see GM negative two point seven
percent four down negative one point one
percent Fiat Chrysler down eight point
six percent Toyota down 2.6 percent BMW
down 12.6% Mazda down nine point three
percent and what we're seeing here is
that the automobile industry it's taking
its hit right now and when we really
look at it what is going on well we have
a lot of soaring defaults on subprime
auto loans that means there's a lot of
people that just aren't going out buying
the cars the ones that have purchased
the cars guess what they're defaulting
on their loans they've went all the way
to the bottom trying to get subprime
people in to take these loans they got
the loans and now they're defaulting on
them we see
negative equity in trade ins as a result
of years of lengthening loan terms and
rolling everything over and it can't be
sustained this way it just doesn't work
and going into 2018 it's just gonna get
worse because it's gonna be a lot of
more people losing their jobs more
retail stores are gonna close more
corporations and remember these
corporations they have a maken they
haven't been making profits sales
they've been buying back their stocks
they've been taking out cheap money
they've been shutting different
locations down to make their earnings
look good which are completely different
then revenue and sales we see the
brick-and-mortar meltdown is now
reaching movie theaters so we've have
the retail industry with stores
brick-and-mortar stores we have
restaurants traffic is declining sales
and restaurants are declining automobile
industry is declining now it's hitting
movie theaters and when you look at this
you say well wait a minute how could it
be movie theaters I mean the last Jedi
just came out I made 517 million well if
we go back in time we see the Star Wars
movie the force has awakened that made
900 something million dollars now yes
the last Jedi has longer to go but at
the same time period the other movie
made a lot more money and if we look at
this we can see that ticket sales are
going down less people are going to the
theaters prices of tickets are moving up
and yes this could kick a lot of people
out saying you know I'm not gonna pay
that high price and what we're seeing
right now is that it's starting to hit
the entertainment industry the number of
actual tickets sold in the u.s. movie
theaters in 2017 fell by 3.6 percent
year-over-year now this is according to
the numbers this is a site that
calculates all this and collects all the
data
and what we're looking at right now is
that the peak
ticket sales they are down 21 percent
since 2002 this tells us that we've been
seeing a decline since that period of
time and it's accelerating and as the
price of tickets move up less people can
afford it as the price of food out in
restaurants moves up less people can
afford it as people lose their jobs
people don't go out to the movies people
don't go out to dinner and this is
exactly what we're seeing right now
movie theaters have been trying to
combat this by redoing their theaters
they're putting in recliner chairs wider
chairs making it feel like you're
watching the movie in your living room
but it doesn't seem to work right now it
looks like a lot of people are saying
you know what I'm opting out right now
I'm not going to be going to the
theaters and what's even more
interesting is that the major production
houses like Warner Brothers Walt Disney
Paramount Pictures Sony's Sony Pictures
and Universal they noticed this and
there's been a downward trend since the
recession where they're releasing less
and less movies in 2017 they released
just 79 movies down 38% since 2006 so
what we're seeing here is a
deterioration in different sectors right
now and it's it's coming out into the
open showing that there are problems and
we can see right now that this is going
to continue and remember most of these
theaters are near malls or inside of
moles and we know that the traffic in
malls have been drying up and if these
theaters if they start to close down
because they're not getting the ticket
sales and they can't make a profit it's
going to affect the malls and it's going
to be a domino effect and it's going to
be absolutely terrible we see the
services PMI syncs to six months lows as
confidence tumbles we also see the
housing markets not just here in the
United States and Canada but we're also
seeing the housing markets
they're beginning to crack in Australia
New Zealand London now property values
they're all starting to crash Australia
home prices fell in the final three
months of 2017 we're also seeing it in
New Zealand we're seeing it in London
and what we're seeing right now is that
the whole thing is starting to
completely fall apart now what's very
interesting is that a lot of these homes
were purchased by foreign buyers and
that is starting to drive back
especially the Chinese because they're
starting to redirect their investments
back into their own country into the
belt and Road and away from real estate
and remember the everyday person is not
out there purchasing these homes they're
not going out taking a mortgage because
a lot of these people they are barely
hanging on many people can't find a high
paying job many people can't find jobs
at all and what we're seeing is that
it's completely falling apart and
whenever a housing starts to decline
so does consumer spending and guess what
you get the economic downturn we've seen
this time and time again and it's
happening once again so the economy is
deteriorating it's spreading to all
different sectors it's spreading to
countries and we're starting to see all
this happen all at once now at the same
time that this is happening we see and
as we know we discussed this before the
petrol you one has been tested they said
it was going to go live after Christmas
and it looks like it is slated to go
live on January 18th that's when they
expect to start this and the Shanghai
International Energy exchange a unit of
the Shanghai Futures Exchange will allow
Chinese buyers to lock in oil prices and
pay in local currency also foreign
traders will be allowed to invest a
first for China's commodities market
because the exchange is registered in
Shanghai's free trade zone and like I
said the trading is going to start
January 18th why is this important for
China because Futures Trading would
some control over pricing from the main

on dollars denominating oil contracts in
yuan would promote the use of China's
currency in global trade one of the
country's key long-term goals and China
would benefit from having a benchmark
that reflects the grades of oil that are
mostly consumed by local refineries and
differ from those underpinning Western
contracts how do you choose work well
future contracts fixed prices today for
delivery at a later date consumers use
them to protect against higher prices
down the line speculators use them to
bet on where prices are headed in 2017
oil futures contracts in new york and
london outstripped physical trading by a
factor of 23 crude oil is among the most
actively traded commodities with two
benchmarks West Texas Intermediate or WT
i-- which trades on the New York
Mercantile Exchange and Brent crude
which trades on ice Futures Europe in
London
why didn't China begin training futures
until now well lower crude prices have
played a part Chinese all Chinese oil
futures well they were proposed in 2012
following spikes above $100 a barrel but
prices in 2017 have averaged little more
than $50 a barrel
there's also concern over volatility
trying to introduce domestic crude
futures in 1993 only to stop a year
later because of volatility and it looks
like they worked out all the problems
and this has been in the works for some
time could the yuan challenge the
dollars dominance and oil yes it could
but it could take a couple of years
since most of the world right now trades
oil using the dollars but it would
happen slowly and this is what the
central bankers like they like things to
happen slowly so you don't notice it
and remember China is creating the
belton road so on the other hand paying
you wan for oil could become part of the
one belt one road initiative and this
would develop ties across your a
Middle East it would allow the Chinese
to participate in soundies Aramco's
planned initial public offerings they
could help the Saudi opinion toward

with the economy completely falling

initiative time all these different
areas together having the Petra you want

they've been doing has been done over
time it's not like yesterday they flew
they they flipped a switch and
everything just moved everything has

methodically they take their time and
make sure that no one really notices it
and the corporate media that there
they're not looking at this at all and
what we're seeing right now is they're

everything comes back and the

they can say listen we need to go to a

and we need to get away from the other

we're getting very close to that stage
and when we go through this transition
period
well it's going to take everything that
